issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: The product is working as designed.
resolution.name: Not a Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
I ran out of disk space on my single frontend (CLC+SC are co-homed) and when I looked at the metadata_volumes table in the eucalyptus_cloud DB, there was a java stack trace in there!

{code}
eucalyptus_cloud=# select * from metadata_volumes;
id | creation_timestamp | last_update_timestamp | metadata_perm_uuid | version | metadata_display_name | metadata_last_state | metadata_state |
metadata_state_change_stack | metadata_account_name | metadata_account_id | metadata_unique_name | metadata_user_id | metadata_user_nam
e | metadata_volume_localdevice | metadata_volume_parentsnapshot | metadata_volume_partition | metadata_volume_remotedevice | metadata_volume_sc_name | metadata_volume_size

Extending the volume and restarting CLC and its now clean:

I was trying to perform some volume operations (specifically an attach) whilst the frontend was out of disk space (this was how I spotted the issue).
fields.summary: When SC machine runs out of disk space, Java stack trace dump appears in DB after error

comments.body: Working as designed.  The clc will retain stack traces with in the db for certain events and actions.

Hey [~kedwards],

How many events need to occur in order for the DB to be cleared of these errors?  There are some errors we see in EUCA-7232 that seem to be causing some odd behavior regarding EMI registration, and wanted to see how many transactions need to be done in order to clear this issue up.
